Mine has been a tale of horrors, I have reached
their acme and what I must now relate can
but be tedious to you.Know that, one by one, my friends
were snatched away; I was left desolate. My own
strength is exhausted; and I must tell in few words
what remains of my hideous narration.

I arrived at Geneva. My father and Ernest
yet lived; but the former sunk under the tidings
that I bore. I see him now, excellent and venerable old
man; his eyes wandered in vacancy for they had lost
their charm and delight. His neice, his more than daugh
